posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

Hi everyone,

I'm relatively new to PCB design, and I'm currently working on my PCB schematic. It involves CAN traces, which include connections like CN1 (a WAGO connector for power) and CN2-4 (WAGO connectors for CAN signals). Since I only need one pair of CAN wires per device, I plan to cut off the excess wires.

My PCB design will consist of four layers:
- Top layer: CAN traces
- Next layer: Ground plane
- Power layer
- One blank copper layer

I've used an online calculator to determine differential impedance and came across a value of 0.2104 mm for dielectric thickness. However, I'm unsure if this accounts for the ground plane beneath the traces. Should dielectric thickness include the ground plane?

This is where I'm getting stuck. Any guidance would be greatly appreciated! ðŸ˜Š

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
On the RJ45, pairs 3-4 are not suitable for Ethernet twisted pair. Instead, use either 1-2, 3-6, 4-5, or 7-8 for a CAN Controller Area Network (CAN) connection. Note that splitting a pair for DC power isn't significantly problematicâ€”if unused wires are present, consider running ground on 4&5 and 12V on 3&6.  

For a small PCB, impedance matching isn't critical. Iâ€™ve successfully used 2-layer connector boards without considering impedance settings, and CAN networks function effectively at 1Mbps.  

Using the same connector for multiple purposes on a single board is risky. I utilized a 5-pin JST-XH connector to carry 12V, GND, 5V, CAN-H, and CAN-L signals. If only CAN functionality was required, I could limit the signal usage to two pins. Additionally, our buck converters were capable of handling the shared ground between the 12V and 5V systems.  

PTCs were incorporated to protect power rails from shorts. Each connector had one PTC, ensuring that a fault in a single load would isolate only that load, not the entire power rail.  

The total distance between the copper layers determines the differential impedance requirement. (Do not factor in the thickness of copper layers or non-participating layers when measuring this distance.)

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: Wow this is some very useful advice thank you so much

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Donâ€™t forget that capacitance to ground plane(s) will affect the impedance of the system.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: So then what do I put into the Altium calculator? Or do I need to do those 70 formulas they keep talking about?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I have not attempted stripline calculations before. I would start by measuring the standard thickness of the FR4 material between layers, checking the copper thickness, and then using a calculator to determine the appropriate trace width and spacing. I would also consider whether the traces are placed on the ground plane on top, bottom, or neither.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: Another thing. What exactly is the purpose of the ground plane in this scenario? I'm not connecting it to the CAN H or CAN L lines; instead, I'm replacing the ground trace for the power of the CANcoder with a ground plane. How does that help reduce interference?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Shielding and control of impedance. Without the ground plane in the PCB, a close aluminum part will change your impedance. It's been a long time since I looked at stripline calculations! Although I'm a mechanical engineer...

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: This is essentially the same as the Swyft CANnect system. The SWYFT CANnect Wiring System is a product offered by SWYFT Robotics. No harm in doing your own setup though.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
On the RJ45, 3-4 is not a twisted pair on Ethernet cable. 1-2, 3-6, 4-5, and 7-8 are, so use one of those for CAN. (Edit: my bad: youâ€™re splitting a pair for DC power. That isnâ€™t as bad. If you donâ€™t have any use for the extra wires, you might as well run GND on 4&5 and 12V on 3&6.) 
For a small PCB…
